round.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: surrounding or on all sides of something or someone
round.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: We sat round the table playing cards.
Gather round! I have an important announcement to make.
He put his arm gently round her waist.
I kept the key on a chain round my neck.
The ballroom’s huge, with windows all the way round.
There was a lovely courtyard with tables all round.
round.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: used to say that someone or something turns so that they face in the opposite direction
round.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: When he turned round I recognised him immediately.
Graham glanced round, startled by the voice behind him.
round.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: in or to many places or parts of an area
round.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Reggie went round making sure all the lights were off.
Leah showed me round on my first day at the office.
A guide took us round the palace and gardens.
He spent a whole year travelling round Europe.
She looked round the room as though leaving it for the last time.
changes that are affecting the weather all round the world
round.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: She watched the clock hands go round.
An aeroplane was circling round far overhead.
Until the 16th century people believed that the Sun went round the Earth.
He stared at the washing machine, just watching the clothes go round and round.
a shoal of tiny fish swimming round in circles
round.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: if you go round to someone’s house, you go to their house, usually to visit them
round.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: I might go round to Nigel’s this evening.
He’s invited us round for dinner.
We’ll be round  (=will arrive) at seven.
round.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: A big box of chocolates was handed round.
round.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: on the other side of something, or to the other side of it without going through it or over it
round.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: He ran round to open Kate’s door for her.
There must be another entrance round the back.
I watched the two boys disappear round the corner.
She came round to his side of the desk.
round.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: in the area near a particular place
round.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Much of the countryside round Hinkley Point is given over to agriculture.
He owned all the land round about (=in the surrounding area).
round.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: used to show that someone spends time in a place without doing anything useful
round.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: People were just standing round and not doing anything to help.
round.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: if something is organized round a particular person or thing, it is organized according to their needs, wishes, ideas etc
round.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: Working from home, she could arrange her hours round her children.
He had built his whole existence round her.
round.translation[0].definitions[10].def: a way round a difficult situation or problem is a way to solve it or avoid it
round.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: She’s going to have to buy a car. I can’t see any other way round it.
strategies to get round (=solve) the  problem
round.translation[0].definitions[11].def: used to show the length of a line surrounding something
round.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: The park was about five miles round.
round.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Jamie’s eyes grew round with delight.
round.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a round number or figure is a whole number, often ending in 0
round.translation[1].definitions[3].note: a round hundred/dozen etc (=a complete hundred etc)
round.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: Let’s make it a round figure: say £50?
Altogether, in round figures, there are about three thousand students here.
round.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a round of events is a series of related events, which are part of a longer process
round.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: a third round of peace talks
the Government’s latest round of expenditure cuts
round.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: one of the parts of a competition that you have to finish or win before you can go on to the next part
round.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: I got beaten in the first round.
Two of their candidates made it through to the next round.
the final round of the championship
round.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: I played a round of golf on Sunday morning.
round.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: one of the periods of fighting in a boxing or wrestling match
round.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: if you buy a round of drinks in a bar, you buy drinks for all the people in your group
round.translation[2].definitions[4].exam: What are you having? It’s my round.
round.translation[2].definitions[5].defi: a single shot from a gun, or a bullet for one shot
round.translation[2].definitions[5].exam: I’ve only got ten rounds of ammunition left.
round.translation[2].definitions[6].defi: something that has a circular shape
round.translation[2].definitions[7].defi: a regular visit to a number of houses, offices etc to deliver or sell things
round.translation[2].definitions[7].exam: I used to do a paper round.
round.translation[2].definitions[8].defi: a song for three or four singers, in which each one sings the same tune, starting at a different time
round.translation[2].note_box[0].section: A second round of talks got under way this week.
In the first round of voting he took 44.5 percent of the vote,
The president is likely to approve a new round of cuts in military forces.
The latest round of layoffs could bring its labor force down to 60,000.
What has prompted the latest round of violence?
round.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to go round something such as a bend or the corner of a building
round.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: As they rounded the bend and came in sight of the river, Philip took her hand.
The tide was coming in as he rounded the rocks.
round.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: to make something into a round shape
round.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The stones were then rounded, polished and engraved.
round.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: if your eyes round, you open them wide because you are shocked, frightened etc
round.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: a round number or sum is a whole number, often ending in 0
round.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: Let’s make it a round £50 I owe you.
round.translation[4].definitions[1].defi: when an amount is not expressed as an exact number, but as the nearest 10,100,1, 000 etc
round.translation[4].definitions[1].exam: In round figures, the expected profit is about £600 million.
round.translation[5].definitions[0].defi: a number or set of things that are connected such as a series of meetings or discussions
round.translation[5].definitions[0].exam: The current round of bargaining began on Oct. 23.
Canadian retailers are facing a round of bankruptcies after being hit by one of the worst holiday sales seasons ever.
